instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,

I have dead <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. It had liquid damage around <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> which I cleaned up and ran jumper wires etc. 5V on the USB C power meter.

I have:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.17V
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H_R</SIGNAL> = 0V

Neither are short to gnd. Any help from here would be appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Be sure all resistors around <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> are OK and check continuity to its pins.
Possibly broken trace between <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>/90.
In such case, USB-C controllers never work.

Voltage to <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is PPDCIN 5 volts? If so, replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> as it produces the enable for <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> is 0V. Resistors are OK and have continuity to <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL>=5V but <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>=0V. Don't I need this rail before <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is suspect? The power system on these boards makes my brain hurt.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If you don?t even have PPDCIN check for a short on that line. Also for sure known good 87 watt USBC brick and cable? Also ports aren?t badly corroded?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Compare voltage and resistance to ground (diode mode) at LDO outputs for both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Don't forget to check for short, or low value at <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Will be better if you have known good board, to compare all values.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 47236"]Compare voltage and resistance to ground (diode mode) at LDO outputs for both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Don't forget to check for short, or low value at <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Will be better if you have known good board, to compare all values.[/QUOTE]

No short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>

Faulty board
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.486V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.498V

Good board
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.515V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.515V


[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 47232"]If you don?t even have PPDCIN check for a short on that line. Also for sure known good 87 watt USBC brick and cable? Also ports aren?t badly corroded? [/QUOTE]

No short to gnd on that line. Using a good 87W charger and cable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check all LDO lines.
And compare voltages too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Good board (diode mode):
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0.483V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.515V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>=0.525V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>=0.520V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0.484V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.515V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>=0.525V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>=0.520V

Faulty board (diode mode):
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0V!
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.483V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>=0.526V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>=0V!
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0.494V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.495V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>=0.535V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>=0V!

Faulty board (Voltages):
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>=0.094V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>=1.547V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>=0V

I guess that's why I don't have <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0V!" (diode mode)
So you have a short there.
Check <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>, but I bet <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is the culprit...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You're right of course :) It was <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>. Now I gotta do some reballing. Thanks a lot for the help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, I now have <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>=5V. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is ~2.9V. When I plug the USB C power meter in to the port connected to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> I get 5V and ~400mA but on the port connected to <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> I get 5V ~170mA. Does that sound like <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> is bad as well or that I goofed soldering <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
When you check B port voltages, plug the charger on the corresponding USB-C port.
And compare again with good board.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is low on both cases?
Check it on <RESISTOR>R6999</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Plugged into corresponding ports.
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>=1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>=3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>=1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>=0.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>=1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>=0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>=0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>=0.1V when plugged into port corresponding to B and 2.9V when plugged into A.

Comparing the diode mode readings to the good board they are all very close.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If diode mode readings are correct, voltage values point to internal problem of <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I'll replace <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>, powers on and boots macos :)

Thanks very much for your help.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Glad to hear that.
These USB-C power problems are a nightmare...
